1058092028460916736.text:
When you discover a bug, ask yourself if it's an Oopsie or a Modeling Problem.

An Oopsie is nbd. Write a test, fix it, and move on.

A Modeling Problem is a bug that reveals a fundamental flaw in your program. These are harder to "fix" — but they also lead to the biggest wins.

1024883440271810560.text: This is a cool idea. One tradeoff: it's harder to opt in to patch or minor upgrades, but lots of JS package management ecosystem exists to turn off this feature anyways. Maybe not a bad tradeoff? I'm interested to see what it feels like to use this.

1024882920941481985.text: "To override this default, developers tell the package manager, “no, use at least Y,” and then the package manager can trivially decide which version to use. The versions chosen are minimal and the system as a whole is also minimal, avoiding the complexity of existing systems."

1024882479386116097.text: "This proposal takes a different approach, which I call minimal version selection. It defaults to using the oldest allowed version of every package involved in the build. This decision does not change from today to tomorrow, because no older version will be published."

1024882357935820800.text: "Package managers today use the newest allowed version of packages. I think this is wrong. “Newest allowed version” can change from new versions being published. Tonight someone introduces a new version. Tomorrow the same commands you ran today produces a different result."

946098669538836481.text: It feels like 15% is high enough that fans of @flow and @typescriptlang could claim success, and low enough that dynamic fans will say "look how much work it was for that small payoff."

946098394820251649.text: I didn't see anything about the severity of the bugs prevented or the time it took to add types, so it feels too early to say "look, types in your JS make you 15% better" but it is an interesting result.

946097950857367552.text:
Lots of discussion on static vs dynamic types leans on anecdote. This paper looks at how many bugs @flow and @typescriptlang would have prevented: https://blog.acolyer.org/2017/09/19/to-type-or-not-to-type-quantifying-detectable-bugs-in-javascript/ ….

TL,DR: Either would have prevented about 15% of bugs found in a sample of public GitHub issues.

922099967702867969.text: My gut feeling is the average dev interview process is more humane than it was a few years ago, but most don't consider tradeoffs.

922098778651312129.text: If you really value open source it makes sense to weight public contributions. You still miss out on people who would do it but haven't yet.

922098492125753346.text: Ideally you'd design a process that reflects the kind of culture you want. That is hard but a nice goal.

922098391630278656.text: My point is that when designing an interview process you should recognize the tradeoffs you're making, because you have to make them.

922097759812911104.text:
Referrals, or "Just hire your friends":
People who aren't your friends

922097354186006529.text:
Pair programming:
People prone to anxiety, people who don't pair program a lot

922097178801184770.text:
Take home example projects:
I've heard many devs say they won't do them b/c they don't like working for free.

922096944586952705.text:
Looking at public stuff on GitHub:
People whose work isn't public, people who don't put code on GitHub in their free time.

922096576281034752.text:
Whiteboard interviews:
Non-CS grads, people who don't study up, or just CS grads who've forgetting algorithmic brain puzzlers

922096391014326272.text: For every interview process, there are devs who are qualified to do the work that will do poorly in it.
